Ioic,

In the end, I think experience is the most reliable guide.  Most
dev=
elopers have experience already about tests they should have
written: they'=
re the tests that would have prevented the bugs that
have hurt you worst.  =
As you get more experienced, the maxim of "test
until fear turns to boredom=
" is wise.  If you have a good
test-coverage tool, that can help generate f=
ear, when you ask yourself
"I don't have a single unit test running this me=
thod.  Am I OK with
that?"

One of my personal favorite ways to bootstrap e=
xperience is
test-driven development: every time all your tests pass, and y=
ou're
satisfied with the design of your code so far, write a test for your
=
next feature, which will break, and then make it pass.

Does that help?

  =
 David Saff

>

uther guidance? The question which unit test to do is as important as the q=
uestion how to do unit test because if we don't do the good unit tests then=

thin the programmers teams.
